posts.title: Tottenham Hotspur striker Harry Kane makes Man City Champions League prediction
posts.text:
Daniel Murphy 19:00, 4 APR 2019 Sport Harry Kane playing at the new Tottenham Hotspur stadium (Image: Tottenham Hotspur FC/Tottenham Hotspur FC via Getty Images) Get the biggest Manchester City FC Harry Kane has predicted that the first leg of the Champions League quarter-final between Man City and Tottenham Hotspur will be 'something special.'
The clash will be the second game to take place in Tottenham's new state of the art stadium, which is sure to heighten the occasion.
Spurs finally moved into their new home on Wednesday after playing at Wembley for the last two seasons and it certainly was an impressive sight.
Tottenham marched to a 2-0 victory against Crystal Palace and were roared on by a new capacity 62,000 crowd, with 17,500 of them sitting in the South Stand behind the goal that has been dubbed 'The Wall'.
After playing in the maiden win at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, Kane expects Tuesday's quarter-final to be just as spectacular an occasion.

“We have got to try to use the occasion and the atmosphere to our advantage but it will be difficult.”

Kane said the new stadium immediately felt like home and, as he alludes to, it could be a big advantage for Spurs when City travel to the stadium for the first time.
However, City have a good recent record against Spurs and haven't lost against them since 2016.
It looks set to be a thrilling European encoutner.

thread.title: Gravitating towards a Cruyffian theme amidst the 'constants'
thread.title_full: Gravitating towards a Cruyffian theme amidst the 'constants'

posts.title: Gravitating towards a Cruyffian theme amidst the 'constants'
posts.text:
Viber Copy this link Johan Cruyff (1947-2016) passed away three years ago at the age of 68 but his ideas continue to shape the world of football. Photo: Twitter Abdullah Al Mehdi
One usually associates high-calibre football and excitement-inducing matchups -- both in terms of individual players and team-game levels -- with the UEFA Champions League. But over the last few seasons, while the quality was there, the excitement was not as prevalent -- a facet undoubtedly compounded by Real Madrid's three back-to-back titles as the real giants of the competition kept the dramatic effect to a minimum while also creating some spectacles.
However, the recent round of 16 ties threw up some unexpected results to break the pattern. Some balance was achieved through the slaying of giants and then there were a few worthy constants and a glimpse at the fantasia that the upcoming matches can produce.
For drama to unfold, the right ingredients need to be there and this time around the Champions League held the right cards in its deck. Old patterns emerged in new ways and there was late drama, historical comebacks and moments that harkened back to the competitive nature of football itself even amidst the structural financial foothold that the top clubs have achieved in recent years. Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi continued their decade-long dominance in the UCL. Their egregious talent and ravenous hunger once again lit up football. Photo: AFP
An age old saying came to be true this time around in the form of Johan Cruyff's: "Why couldn't you beat a richer club? I've never seen a bag of money score a goal". And it came to fruition in the most tremendous of ways as Ajax slayed the proverbial dragon of the Champions League – 13-time winners and the victors in four of the past five editions, Real Madrid. For a club from a less powerful domestic competition, it was easily their greatest night in recent memory.
The vast disparity in financial muscle between the sides can be fathomed from the mere fact that Real Madrid's Gareth Bale was earning the same wage package as the entire Ajax side. In the end though, when it mattered, Ajax tore the reigning champions to bits at their impregnable fortress, the Santiago Bernabeu, scoring four goals, each more impressive than the last.
When it mattered, a young Ajax side showed collective superiority and maturity beyond their years, invoked their Cruyffista spirit; fast and incisive against a top team who had prevailed so many times in the past. Madrid had prevailed in the first leg too, winning 2-1 even as Ajax dominated, but the Dutch side's 4-1 victory meant they had won at the Spanish giants' home for the third time in history after 1973 and 1995. The last two times it happened, they had won the competition and although it might be an idea 'too far out there', the composure and flair shown by a young side against a star-studded Real outfit means that the romantic notion might not be too misplaced.
Spectacle was ensured elsewhere too as Manchester United pulled off the impossible under dramatic circumstances at the Parc des Princes against Paris Saint-Germain. No team in the history of the coveted competition had gone through after a 2-0 defeat at home but United did it with an entire first-choice lineup absent in Nemanja Matic, Ander Herrera and Paul Pogba along with the absences of Juan Mata, Jesse Lingard, Alexis Sanchez and Anthony Martial. By the time Marcus Rashford had scored from the penalty spot after a debatable penalty decision to send United into ecstasy, the Red Devils had academy products Mason Greenwood (making his debut) and Tahith Chong on the field -- a case in point for clubs building their legacy through youth structure, a hallmark of their glory days under Sir Alex Ferguson when 'The Class of 92' used to reserve the telling blow for the end.
For PSG and all their lavish spending around a project to compete with the best in the business, they are yet to make it past the quarterfinals stage this decade. Florentino Perez and Nasser Al-Khelaifi may have been left scratching their heads because money simply does not buy ideas.
It was also telling how differently the two matches in consecutive nights panned out, but where they converged was the use of youth structure to usurp better, more experienced opponents. In a way, the round of 16 was paying homage to one of Cruyff's footballing ideologies' key tenets -- clubs bringing through academy products.
The round of 16 had surprises up its sleeve the following weekend too when Juventus resurrected themselves by overturning a 2-0 first-leg deficit against a staunch Atletico Madrid defence in the return leg.
Over the past few seasons, the Champions League had seen some major turnarounds. Barca overturned a 4-0 deficit in 2016 against PSG and Roma did it against the Catalans last season, overcoming a 4-1 deficit. The frequency of turnarounds in this season's round of 16 phase was however unprecedented. It was almost surreal for a tournament known for its caution and caginess.
There was a signature to these games. From Atletico, PSG and Real through to Barca last season -- some of the biggest names in the competition were ceding control of tight matches. It was once again Cruyff's principles towering over the modern game. The great man, whose Ajax and Barcelona sides -- where he both thrived as player and coach, always, in layman's term, talked about suffocating the opponent by 'controlling the ball'. What he and his mentor Rinus Michels however did -- the key facet of the modern game -- was to reimagine football as a highly skilled spatial contest.
Diego Simeone's Atletico follow some of those Total Footballing traits of counter-pressing and controlling space too but they gave up control when they failed to use the ball well and suffered greatly for it.
You protect space, you conserve space, you use the ball to control the space you need and you concede space you do not need at given phases, and a most importantly, Cruyff's idea was controlling that space in relation to the position of the ball along with positional superiority of the players.
The modern game, while driven by money and power-football through physical attributes, has also attained a more technical level both in terms of how coaches and players think about the game.
In its chess-like qualities, modern football is more a 'coach's game'. The structure, forms and stylistic elements that run through all of football but especially in the cautiously-approached Champions League ties have to do with the broader spectrum of effective coaching in the modern game. Total football has not completely changed the landscape but with a greater degree of managerial pedigree coming through with the likes of Jurgen Klopp, Diego Simeone, Mauricio Pochettino and Pep Guardiola setting new standards, its impact on football is gaining prominence, in fact shaping it.
But even amidst the governing managerial doctrines shaping football, there existed a familiarity in the shape of 'constants'. Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi remained the constants amidst this chaotic round of 16 results. The duo keep evolving, adapting to waning physical capabilities and changes in their footballing environment. Ronaldo hit a hattrick to take Juve through and Messi swept aside Lyon with two goals and two assists. They define this era like no other. The prospect of a mouth-watering face-off between the two can only happen in the final but before that they have business to attend to in the quarterfinals.
This round was rich in excitement and amidst the opposing ideas grinding it out, a breath of fresh air was found with the return to a more competitive norm, gravitating towards a more Utopian Cruyffian theme.
The Dutch master passed away three years ago but in its own way, the game continues to pay its respect. A true master lives in the heart of his pupils and Europe's top club competition continued to show his overarching influence. A right to fight, to battle, no matter who the opponent. A return to the spirit of competitiveness no matter what means you have. The vision of a collective game was thriving. "In a way I'm probably immortal," he had said. Of course the father of modern football was right as always. Related Topics

posts.author: Scott Saunders
posts.title: Manchester United Transfers: How Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's Team Could Look in 2019/20
posts.text:
Manchester United have some big decisions to make this summer.
The potential for high-profile exits - Paul Pogba and David de Gea are being consistently linked with moves away - is looming large at the moment following a recent form dip. But the current media talk goes heavy on United's determination to spend big and address issues that have been holding the team back for years.
United fans will certainly hope their club can spend in the right places, and the latest reports suggest they could be ready to ​axe as many as six players , while signing another five.
Saw some footage of him on youtube. He's class
— Hambali Ramly (@HambaliRamly_) April 4, 2019 Figures from between £200m-£300m have been floated as the potential outlay on the playing staff. Perhaps more dependent on player sales - maybe a Chinese Super League club will pay £100m for ​Alexis Sanchez ? So we're going to imagine spending big money (£400m probs) by buying five players, fitting them in to the new-look team for next season at the same time.
Remember, this is fantasy and in no way are we saying this is going to happen. But nevertheless, we're going to try and build a team that works, and a system that has balance, basing it on the speculation that's come and gone around United's likely business.
They want an "English core", y'know...
David de Gea
United have problem, and that's ​David de Gea 's contract. It's up next summer, but the club are determined to dig their heels in and work out an extension - even while the player is looking to become one of the best paid players at the club.
It'd take a huge offer to convince United to sell this year, but they'll need to be careful - the Spaniard could walk away for free in 2020.
Aaron Wan-Bissaka
Crystal Palace full back Aaron Wan-Bissaka is one of the Premier League's most wanted , and United are right at the front of the queue to sign the £40m-rated star.
Roy Hodgson has admitted Palace will sell for the right price, so it's all about getting this one done quickly. United may have Diogo Dalot's promise to nurture, but they don't have much else to rely on. Right back is a crucial position to strengthen.
You want Ashley Young playing in this position next season? No, of course you don't.
Victor Lindelof
The Swede has proven himself as United's first choice central defender this season. He's been very good barring the odd below-par game (most of which have come recently) and looks to have all the tools to actually succeed at Old Trafford.
He's only 24, remember, so there's still plenty more to come - but Lindelof could do with someone of the highest quality alongside him.
Kalidou Koulibaly
And no, we don't mean Chris Smalling or Phil Jones. United must spend big on a centre half this summer - a man at the top of their game - and Kalidou Koulibaly will fit the bill.
He won't come cheap. The touted fee is in the region of £90m at the moment, but United need someone to have an impact on their defence at the levels that Virgil van Dijk has hit at Liverpool - as painful as it is to say. It'll make a world of difference, and potentially take them up a level.
Latest talk is that the Senegalese has switched agents with the ambition of leaving Napoli, so watch this space.
Luke Shaw
​Shaw has been one of United's most consistent performers this season, winning the club's player of the month award three times, and he should retain his place next season regardless.
United do need cover at left back, but it's not the most crucial part of the squad to address at the moment.
Declan Rice
Nemanja Matic turns slower than it takes Earth to do one full rotation on its axis, so Manchester United need a new defensive midfielder for next season. Declan Rice looks the real deal, he's English - not Irish - and he looks an actual realistic target. He's excellent at bringing the ball forward from deep, distributes well and his first touch is exemplary.
West Ham have, similarly to Palace, admitted they'll sell the 20-year-old for the right price (going to pluck £50m out of the air here) so it's a worthwhile investment.
Saul Niguez
Okay, we're entering dreamland now. United's latest high-profile transfer target is Atletico Madrid's Saul Niguez, and he will cost a lot, a lot (a lot) of money if they do end up landing him.
How much? Anywhere between €120m and €150m. What a signing he'd be mind you.
​Andrew Headspeath has written this ​excellent piece on why he'd be the perfect fit .
​Paul Pogba
​Paul Pogba might have his head turned, his agent might be turning it for him, or he might be completely happy in Manchester. You can expect this transfer saga to run and run as Real Madrid try and spend £8bn of "their own money" throughout this summer transfer window.
However, the World Cup winner is a huge commercial asset for United, as well as a huge asset on the pitch, and he has two years (with an option to extend for a third) on his contract.
Good luck trying to buy him.
Jadon Sancho​
Jadon Sancho has been dubbed " ​Manchester United 's number one transfer target" for a number of weeks now, and you can see why.
England's latest international star is lightning quick, direct, tricky and hungry to prove himself in the Premier League, and while United were recently said to be writing the deal off because of expense, they have a penchant for signing the big names. Sancho is nearly there.
If they don't want to blow another £100m, PSV's Chucky Lozano is a cheaper alternative option at around £35m. But this Sancho chat could run and run.
Anthony Martial
Having signed a new contract recently, it's now time for ​Tony Marshall to get down to business and start showing his quality on a consistent basis.
United fans know he's got it in his locker, but it's time to deliver on that potential for the Frenchman. He's got his chance now.

thread.title: The surprising Anthony Martial stat that sees him ranked third among Premier League's top strikers
thread.title_full: The surprising Anthony Martial stat that sees him ranked third among Premier League's top strikers - Manchester Evening News

posts.author: David Alexander Hughes
posts.title: The surprising Anthony Martial stat that sees him ranked third among Premier League's top strikers
posts.text:
The surprising Anthony Martial stat that sees him ranked third among Premier League's top strikers The Frenchman has had one of his better seasons at Old Trafford since arriving in 2015. Share Sport MANCHESTER, ENGLAND - MARCH 30: Anthony Martial of Manchester United celebrates after scoring his team's second goal during the Premier League match between Manchester United and Watford FC at Old Trafford on March 30, 2019 in Manchester, United Kingdom. (Photo by Shaun Botterill/Getty Images) Get the biggest Manchester United FC
Anthony Martial has gone through up and down periods since arriving at Manchester United back in 2015.
After a slow start, the Frenchman enjoyed a successful spell under Louis van Gaal scoring 11 goals and assisting four in his debut season at Old Trafford. However, he suffered a fractured relationship with manager Jose Mourinho thereafter.
The pari's relationship reached boiling point last summer when Martial returned to France from the club's pre-season tour of the United States for the birth of his child.
The player's agent Philippe Lamboley was even quoted as stating Martial wanted to leave because United had not demonstrated they wanted make the then 23-year-old "an important member of the team".
But the departure of Mourinho and arrival of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer was followed by a new contract for the Frenchman that will keep him at United until June 2024, with the option to extend for a further year. Read More Manchester United told how much Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Wilfried Zaha could cost
This has come on the back of a season where Martial has been a key player for United, making 32 appearances across all competitions. Of those appearances, 23 came in the league.
Under the Norwegian, he has often been favoured in a front three with Marcus Rashford and Jesse Lingard.
He can boast a decent record of ten goals from those 23 matches, that’s one short of his highest total since arriving in the Premier League. Notably however this season, 19 other Premier League players can better that total, including the likes of Brighton’s Glen Murray, Bournemouth's Callum Wilson and Arsenal's Alexandre Lacazette.
More worrying is the fact that he has managed just two league assists all campaign. With just six league matches to go, it looks set to be his lowest league assist total since arriving at the club. Anthony Martial's Premier League Goals and Assists since arriving (Image: @DAHughes_) Follow tactics writer David Hughes on social media
To follow David on Twitter, click here.
He therefore ranks 25th overall in the Premier League in terms of combined goals and assists, with the likes of Sergio Augero, Mohammed Salah and Raheem Sterling all leading the way with upwards of 20 goals and assists this season.
Looking at the underlying numbers, should his abrupt decline in creativity be a concern?
Assessing the Expected Assist (xA) metric for the season, which looks at the quality of the pass to a player who then takes a shot on goal and gives it a value, irrespective of if that shot leads to a goal, we can assess the quality of his final ball.
For example, if a player has an xA for the season of ten, but they had registered just three assists, then this would demonstrate that the player has been extremely creative, but poor finishing by team-mates means the player only possesses three assists on their record.
In Martial’s case, his xA total is just 2.62. This indicates his tally of two is about right given the quality of his final ball.
For comparison, Raheem Sterling leads the xA charts this season with a league total of 10.64 and Chelsea’s Eden Hazard can boast a total of 8.24. Read More

posts.title: Man Utd flop Eric Bailly is shock £35m transfer target for Real Madrid with Zidane a big fan
posts.text:
EFL time to bail Man Utd flop Eric Bailly is shock £35m transfer target for Real Madrid with Zidane a big fan
Zinedine Zidane is understood to be a huge fan of the Ivorian defender following his previous spell in La Liga Exclusive 4th April 2019, 6:21 pm Updated: 4th April 2019, 6:22 pm REAL MADRID are shock £35m contenders to sign Manchester United central defender Eric Bailly in the summer.
The Old Trafford central defender is understood to be ready to move on after being plagued by injuries and falling down the pecking order this season. Getty - Contributor 1 Eric Bailly has made just 13 starts for Manchester United in all competitions this season
His camp are also aware of reports new boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is looking to reinforce his options at the heart of the Red Devils’ rearguard in the close season.
However, sources close to Bailly have heard bosses at the Bernabeu have him on a list of first-tier options, having been beaten to the punch by United when he left Spanish side Villarreal back in 2016 for £30m.
Real boss Zinedine Zidane is understood to remain a fan of the player from his previous time in La Liga and Bailly’s name has been put forward to the legendary Frenchman.
Bailly still has 15 months left on his deal at United but talks over an extension have been left on the back burner, which has only added to the Ivory Coast international’s frustration.
The powerful 24-year-old was Jose Mourinho’s first signing when he was appointed but even the Portuguese tactician was running thin on patience towards the end of his tenure.
He has made started just 13 games in all competitions this season and he remains a huge doubt for the Champions League quarter-final clash against Barcelona.
Solskjaer's side could propose a player-plus-cash deal including Bailly to increase their chances of luring Raphael Varane away from the Bernabeu. latest man utd news

thread.title: Samuel Chukwueze, la prochaine grosse vente de Villarreal
thread.title_full: Samuel Chukwueze, la prochaine grosse vente de Villarreal

posts.author: Alexis Pereira
posts.title: Samuel Chukwueze, la prochaine grosse vente de Villarreal
posts.text:
Accueil > La Liga Santander > Transferts > Samuel Chukwueze, la prochaine grosse vente de Villarreal Samuel Chukwueze, la prochaine grosse vente de Villarreal Publié le : Alexis Pereira Suivre @apereira__ Après Eric Bailly, Cédric Bakambu et Rodri, Villarreal devrait à nouveau recevoir un gros chèque pour Samuel Chukwueze. L'attaquant nigérian, étincelant face au FC Barcelone mardi, figure sur les tablettes de grands d'Europe. Et son prix est déjà conséquent ! Samuel Chukwueze promet de rapporter gros à Villarreal ! ©Maxppp
Villarreal a l’habitude de réaliser une grosse vente chaque été. En 2015, Luciano Vietto partait à l’Atlético de Madrid pour 20 M€. L’année suivante, Éric Bailly s’envolait pour Manchester United contre un chèque de 40 M€. En 2017, l’ancien Sochalien Cédric Bakambu rejoignait la Chine et le Beijing Guoan pour environ 37 M€. L’été dernier, l’Atlético mettait 25 M€ sur la table pour attirer Rodri dans ses filets. Cet été, c’est Samuel Chukwueze qui pourrait bien perpétuer cette tradition.
L’attaquant nigérian - arrivé de la Diamond Football Academy en 2017 pour environ 500 000€, opération réalisée à la barbe de l’AS Monaco, d’Arsenal et du FC Porto - affole les recruteurs européens. Pour son premier exercice en Liga, le jeune homme de 19 ans affiche un niveau très intéressant et des statistiques prometteuses (4 réalisations et 2 passes décisives en 19 apparitions en championnat). Sa vitesse balle au pied et sa technique en mouvement font des ravages au sein des défenses espagnoles. Une clause à 63 M€ !
Sa dernière prestation, face au FC Barcelone (4-4, 30e journée de Liga), en est la parfaite illustration. Le Super Eagle (1 sélection) a littéralement mis au supplice la charnière 100% tricolore des Blaugranas Clément Lenglet et Samuel Umtiti par ses dribbles chaloupés et sa vitesse. Ce dernier en fait encore des cauchemars. Avec un but plein de puissance et un amour d’offrande de l’extérieur, le natif d’Ikwuano a encore un peu plus conquis les observateurs (le Real Madrid, le FC Barcelone, l’Atlético Madrid et la Premier League ont été annoncés sur ses traces).
Le sous-marin jaune, qui se bat pour son maintien, avait vu venir en lui offrant un contrat professionnel l’été dernier. La révélation du Mondial des moins de 17 ans en 2015 au Chili (7 buts en 7 matches) est désormais liée à l’écurie espagnole jusqu’en juin 2023. Surtout, Villarreal a inclus une clause libératoire - pratique obligatoire en Espagne - qui lui assure une vente lucrative dans les mois à venir. Selon As , il faudra en effet débourser 63 M€ pour le déloger de La Céramica. De quoi déjà se frotter les mains pour le président Fernando Roig.

thread.title: Man City extend impressive Manchester United record with Premier League win over Cardiff
thread.title_full: Man City extend impressive Manchester United record with Premier League win over Cardiff - Manchester Evening News

posts.author: Joe Bray
posts.title: Man City extend impressive Manchester United record with Premier League win over Cardiff
posts.text:
Joe Bray 18:00, 4 APR 2019 Sport 'Noisy neighbours' Manchester City are asserting their dominance over Manchester United. Get the biggest Manchester City FC Three points for Manchester City on Wednesday moved them back above Liverpool in the Premier League title race with just six games remaining - but it also secured another important record.
The win over Cardiff lifted City to a hugely impressive 80 points from 32 games, with a maximum total of 98 points still possible.
Fixtures against Tottenham and Manchester United in the Premier League are the toughest of the remaining games Pep Guardiola's side still have to play, meaning their rivals can have a huge say in the destination of the Premier League trophy.
But even if United put a dent in City's hopes of winning the league, there is no chance of the red half of Manchester lifting the trophy themselves.
That is because City's win against Cardiff took them 19 points clear of United with just 18 points left to play for, meaning City will finish above their neighbours for another season.
Read More Liverpool great insists only a ‘Manchester Utd miracle’ will stop Man City winning title Read More Pep Guardiola makes Phil Foden Man City promise after win vs Cardiff The current gap between the sides is the same as last season, when City blew away the rest of the Premier League in record breaking style.
And City have now finished above United in the league for a sixth successive season, and for the seventh time in the eight seasons since the Blues won their first Premier League title in 2012.
In that time, City have won nine of the 15 league meetings between the sides, and drawn twice.
The current streak is the longest such run of consecutive finishes above United since ten seasons between 1928-29 and 1937-38.
However, United hold the longest streak of finishes above City, with the 20 seasons between 1991-92 and 2010-11.
But the balance of power has shifted in Manchester in recent years, and a win over United at Old Trafford on April 24 for City will only confirm that trend, and go a long way to ensuring another Premier League title at the Etihad.
Read More Relegate Liverpool FC? Bring back Leeds and Villa? Pick the 20 teams who should be in the Premier League Read More Cardiff boss Neil Warnock reveals Man City joke that had Pep Guardiola baffled

thread.title_full: Eric Bailly in Real Madrid's Sights Ahead of Old Trafford Summer Overhaul – Yes, Really

posts.author: Ross Kennerley
posts.title: Eric Bailly in Real Madrid's Sights Ahead of Old Trafford Summer Overhaul – Yes, Really
posts.text:
​Real Madrid have emerged as shock contenders to relieve Eric Bailly from his escalating frustrations at Manchester United, with a summer move on the cards.
The Ivorian defender has been plagued by a combination of injuries and lack of faith from his managers this season, resulting in the 24-year-old making only 13 starts across all competitions, and remaining a doubt for the club's Champions League quarter final clash with Barcelona.
Man Utd flop Eric Bailly is shock summer transfer target for Real Madrid https://t.co/uGo3Uzep3D pic.twitter.com/pzGtZpfcmX
— The Sun Football ⚽ (@TheSunFootball) April 4, 2019
Now it appears, per ​The Sun , that the ​United outcast could be offered an escape route from Old Trafford, with ​Madrid manager Zinedine Zidane still a fan of the player despite a less than fruitful two-and-a-half year stint in Manchester. Prior to the defender's £30m move to England, the Spanish outfit were keen on the player themselves, but were pipped to the post.
Bailly was the first signing of the Jose Mourinho era but never succeeded in nailing down a first team role under his former boss, while Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has preferred Chris Smalling and Victor Lindelof in recent weeks ahead of the crocked centre half.
While there is undoubtedly a talent there, reports of Madrid's interest must be taken with a decent pinch of salt, after the article claims the Red Devils are even considering lining up a player-plus-cash deal with Los Blancos in return for ​Raphael Varane , with the Frenchman currently trying to engineer an exit from the ​La Liga side.
Supposedly, Bailly's camp are aware of Solskjaer's interest in reinforcing his options at the heart of defence, seemingly banishing any hopes the former Villareal player may hold in returning to the first team fold. As such, a summer exit from the ​Premier League appears likely, however, the proposed destination remains unclear.

thread.title: Former Liverpool FC star calls Man City the best Premier League side he's ever seen
thread.title_full: Former Liverpool FC star calls Man City the best Premier League side he's ever seen - Manchester Evening News

posts.author: Daniel Murphy
posts.title: Former Liverpool FC star calls Man City the best Premier League side he's ever seen
posts.text:
Former Liverpool FC star calls Man City the best Premier League side he's ever seen Liverpool are competing neck and neck with Manchester City in the Premier League title race Share Man City players celebrate the opening goal against Cardiff (Image: Tom Flathers/Man City via Getty Images) Get the biggest Manchester City FC
Former Liverpool star Jamie Redknapp has described Man City as the best Premier League side he's ever seen, even better than Arsenal's invincibles and Manchester United's treble winning team.
City once again took the lead in this roller-coaster of a Premier League season on Wednesday night after a dominating 2-0 victory against Cardiff City.
The Blues had 27 shots compared to Cardiff's mere four and had 79% possession. Only an inspired performance from Bluebird's goalkeeper Neil Etheridge kept the score-line repsectable.
The win saw Pep Guardiola's side leapfrog Liverpool into first by a single point, though the Reds will once again have the chance to reclaim top spot when they face Southampton on Friday.
The performance against Cardiff wasn't City's best, yet they completely controlled the proceedings after making several changes. Read More Tottenham Hotspur striker Harry Kane makes Man City Champions League prediction
It showed City's strength in depth and understanding throughout the squad and as a result Redknapp heaped on the praise.
"We’re talking about one of the best sides in the world,” he said on Sky Sports.
“For me, the best side I’ve seen in the Premier League.
“I played against the Invincibles, we saw the United team that were fantastic.
“I just think this side are so good, total football.
“I watched them against Fulham at the weekend, they come at you from every angle.
“Every player on the field had a shot on goal, it’s total football. It’s like the Dutch in the ‘70s.
“They are a wonderful side to watch.” Read More

posts.title: Manchester United midfield target discusses his future amid transfer links
posts.text:
Tyrone Marshall 17:30, 4 APR 2019 Sport United have been linked with a move for Youri Tielemans this summer (Image: Getty Images) Youri Tielemans will keep his options open this summer after being linked with a move to Manchester United .
The Belgium midfielder has impressed at Leicester City since joining the Foxes on loan from Monaco in January.
His performances for Leicester, scoring once and setting up three goals in his seven Premier League appearances, have led to speculation he could make that move permanent this summer.
But the £40million-rated 21-year-old is happy to wait until the window opens to see what his future holds, with United and Tottenham amongst the sides reported to hold an interest in signing him permanently.
"I do not know what is going to happen this summer," he told Sky Sports . "I feel really good here, but I have to see the other options too. That is normal, and I do not have to rush myself.
"We are now in April and we will see over the next months."
Read More Manchester United defender Luke Shaw credits Ole Gunnar Solskjaer for the two things that have helped him improve Tielemans has enjoyed his time at the King Power Stadium however, and he's hinted he would be happy to move to the Midlands on a permanent basis.
"At Leicester, I can be part of something great. They will have a new training ground, the stadium will be much better than it is now with more fans coming over," he said.
"So it can be something great for the future."

thread.title: Transfer Rumours: Ben Yedder to Man Utd, Mount & Abraham to Leipzig, Isak to Barcelona & More
thread.title_full: Transfer Rumours: Ben Yedder to Man Utd, Mount & Abraham to Leipzig, Isak to Barcelona & More

posts.author: Wilfred Laurence
posts.title: Transfer Rumours: Ben Yedder to Man Utd, Mount & Abraham to Leipzig, Isak to Barcelona & More
posts.text:
​Transfers. You love them. We love them. Clubs love them - some of them with careless abandon, some with unrequited distance. Basically, everyone loves transfers.
Which is good, because here's a collection of the latest ones that could happen.
Bundesliga Duo Identify Swansea Youngster as Next British Target
​Bayer Leverkusen and VfL Wolfsburg have identified Swansea City defender Ben Cabango as a candidate to replicate Jadon Sancho's success in the Bundesliga, despite the 18-year-old being yet to register a single first team appearance for the Swans.
According to the ​Sun , the German duo have been scouting Cabango for the last few weeks in his turnouts for the Under-23s and have been impressed with the centre back's maturity. Of course, that 'next Jadon Sancho' label is perhaps misplaced, given that he is neither English nor a winger, but the 'next Rabbi Matondo' - who is Welsh but also a winger - doesn't quite have the same ring.
As it stands, the 'next Reece Oxford' (?) is contracted with the Championship side until 2021, but could be available for as little as £2.5m.
Colchester's Noah Chilvers Tempting West Ham & Leicester
​Premier League pair West Ham United and Leicester City have apparently become enamoured with Colchester United's young up-and-comer Noah Chilvers.
The alarmingly fresh-faced Chilvers - who is not pictured here, that's just a rainy car park outside the JobServe Community Stadium, in case you were confused - made his debut for the first team last month, having impressed for both the Under-18s and Under-23s as an 18-year-old.
The central midfielder, who can also occupy a playmaker role, is yet to sign a professional contract with the U's and could thus be plucked by either the Hammers or the Foxes for just a compensatory fee this summer, according to the ​Sun .
Man Utd Tracking Sevilla Striker Wissam Ben Yedder
​Manchester United are tracking Sevilla centre forward Wissam Ben Yedder as a potential frontline replacement for Alexis Sanchez this summer, according to reports from Spain, as relayed by the ​Sun .
The Frenchman, who dumped the Red Devils out of the Champions League last season with a supremely well-taken brace inside four minutes at Old Trafford, has notched 28 goals and eight assists this season.
That goal tally not only represents the greatest seasonal haul of his career, but also his age, and with his contract set to expire in 2021, he looks set to become a hot commodity this summer. Chelsea Academy Pair Mount & Abraham Targets for RB Leipzig
Continuing the British youth invasion of Germany theme, I offer you ​Chelsea academy graduates Mason Mount and Tammy Abraham.
According to the ​Daily Mail , RB Leipzig have been monitoring the exploits of both Blues loanees in the Championship and have been sufficiently impressed with what they've seen. Of course, the caveat that looms over all Chelsea transfer news right now is the impending fate of their two-window transfer ban.
Should that be upheld, it would be hard to see the club letting go of both these stars, on loan or not. Then again, it was hard to see them letting go of Nathaniel Chalobah and Ruben Loftus-Cheek in the stead of Danny Drinkwater in 2017, but that actually really happened, making the potential for both of these players leaving for no return fairly foreseeable... and a bit more agreeable.
Barcelona Back in for Swedish Prodigy Alexander Isak
Almost ten years after signing Zlatan Ibrahimovic for €69m, ​Barcelona have turned their gaze to the man ascribed with the 'next Zlatan' moniker.
Alexander Isak has been wowing scouts since his early years at Swedish side IAK, but opted against a high-profile switch to Real Madrid, Barça, Bayern or Juventus in 2017 for the slightly less pressured annals of Borussia Dortmund.
However, with ten goals from nine games on loan at Eredivisie side Willem II, the 19-year-old is now considering a move to said big leagues, with La Blaugrana closely monitoring the situation and the German side willing to consider offers, according to ​Mundo Deportivo .

thread.title: Saúl Ñiguez: The Midfielder Who Literally Bleeds for Success Is Worth the Fee for Man Utd
thread.title_full: Saúl Ñiguez: The Midfielder Who Literally Bleeds for Success Is Worth the Fee for Man Utd

posts.author: Andrew Headspeath
posts.title: Saúl Ñiguez: The Midfielder Who Literally Bleeds for Success Is Worth the Fee for Man Utd
posts.text:
"After every match or training session I would pee blood." At just 24, reported Manchester United and City target Saúl Ñiguez has already been through a hell of a lot.
He has played 150 times in La Liga for the club he joined as a youngster, won the Copa del Rey, the Supercopa, the Europa League and been a Champions League runner-up. He won the Golden Boot at the Euro Under-21 Championships. He even left Real Madrid as a teenager.
More unusually, he also played for two seasons with an internal catheter, after a freak collision left him with a kidney haematoma on his ​Champions League debut against Bayer Leverkusen back in 2015.
Saúl later described the pain on Spanish TV (via ​AS ) and how he would literally urinate blood after every training session and game, as he 'gambled' with his health, such was his desire to continue competing.
The all-action midfielder comes from a family of professional footballers. His brother Aaron (five years Saúl's senior) was once touted as a potential superstar after coming through at Valencia, before tearing his knee ligaments.
Saúl's incredible determination meant that not only did he not fade away like his brother and so many other young players with serious injuries, but he actually used it to propel him on.
" What doesn't kill you makes you stronger... I actually played very well with it [the catheter],” he told Sid Lowe in a ​Guardian interview in 2017, after revealing that he once pleaded with the doctors to just take his kidney out.
To those outside of Spain, Saúl is still something of an enigma. His solo effort for ​Atlético Madrid against Bayern Munich in the Champions League semi-final of 2016 (a goal scored with the catheter firmly in place) briefly lifted him to global prominence, before he became just another name in the long line of hugely talented but basically indistinguishable Spanish talents who haven't left the Iberian peninsula.
It is quite easy to ignore Saúl as a Premier League introvert. The first ports of call for Manchester United and City fans reacting to the recent ​transfer links (Wikipedia, Transfermarkt and WhoScored) don't yield much enticing information. Instead, they seem to tell you that he is not much of a goalscorer, nor an assist maker.
He does not have teams built around him and he doesn't even really seem to have a fixed position. He didn't have the most effective of World Cups last summer and with a €150m buyout clause, he seems like one hell of an expensive backup for Fernandinho.
However, he is more than that. Much more. In Saúl, ​Atlético Madrid have a player who couldn't be more suited to Diego Simeone if he was created in a lab; a warrior who can and has played in every outfield position, doing so with lung-busting hunger, skill and intelligence.
On loan at Rayo Vallecano, Saúl was a centre-back, with Spain Under-21s he was an attacker, with the seniors he is box to box, and for Atleti? Well, he has had every last drop of blood squeezed out of him in a deep midfield role, out wide and even covering at left back.
His famous Champions League goal against Bayern nearly three years ago typified the kind of rare talent he is, combining the legacy of tiki-taka with the drive and strength needed to break the lines in the years since Spain ruled the world.
As an example of just how all-action Saúl is, he is in the top three at Atleti this season for: dribbles, passes, shots and tackles.
With big summer spending predicted, Barcelona and Real Madrid would surely take Saúl in a heartbeat. However, Atleti would likely hold their rivals to the contractual buyout clause. That leaves named suitors and rivals ​Manchester United - who have supposedly been tracking Saúl since his Rayo loan days - and ​Manchester City , who were tipped to complete an ​€80m move just a few weeks ago.
With Lucas Hernandez confirmed to leave and Antoine Griezmann and Diego Godin's futures still up in the air, there is something of a feeling of an end of an era at Atletico and maybe the time is right for Saúl to start earning the global recognition he deserves. He's given blood for his career and now could be the time to reap the rewards.
Should a transfer battle ensue this summer, Saúl is a player worth busting a gut for.

thread.title: Manchester United and Man City could save millions in transfer market with potential Premier League changes
thread.title_full: Manchester United and Man City could save millions in transfer market with potential Premier League changes - Manchester Evening News

posts.author: Josh Challies Trainee Sports Wire Writer
posts.title: Manchester United and Man City could save millions in transfer market with potential Premier League changes
posts.text:
Josh Challies Trainee Sports Wire Writer 17:00, 4 APR 2019 Sport Man City manager Pep Guardiola and Man Utd boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. Get the biggest daily Changes to the regulations surrounding agent fees in the Premier League could save Manchester City and Manchester United millions in the transfer market.
The 20 shareholders of Premier League clubs are due to meet on Friday, where a proposal to cut down the fees payable to representatives of players during the summer and winter transfer windows will be discussed.
One of the main changes on the cards is the scrapping of dual regulation, which would see the end of agents being able to command a fee from both the selling and buying club.
Agent fees have become a major talking point in recent years and there are currently no limits or caps involved for work undertaken by an agent in relation to a transfer or contract negotiations - but a report from the Telegraph suggests that is about to change.
Read More Manchester United transfer news LIVE Solskjaer 'fails to agree transfer budget with Woodward' and Saul Niguez latest Read More Manchester City news and transfers LIVE Rodri to Man City latest as Pep Guardiola provides Zinchenko injury update If proposals go ahead, clubs in the Premier League could save a significant amount in the market. It has just been revealed that between February 2018 and January 2019 United spent a whopping £20,759,350 on agents' fees.
Despite only making one signing in that time - Riyad Mahrez - City ecplised that figure by shelling out £24,122,753.
Further changes may also be on the cards with FIFA discussing a potential framework with the Premier League for how transfers and agent payments are regulated moving forward, which could include an exam system for these representatives.
Read More How Manchester United could line up with transfer targets next season Read More Cardiff boss Neil Warnock reveals Man City joke that had Pep Guardiola baffled

posts.author: Joe Bray
posts.title: Manchester United defender Luke Shaw credits Ole Gunnar Solskjaer for the two things that have helped him improve
posts.text:
Sport Manchester United defender Luke Shaw credits Ole Gunnar Solskjaer for the two things that have helped him improve Luke Shaw won Man Utd's Player of the Month for March after a fine run of form under Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. Share Luke Shaw has said what Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has improved at Manchester United. Get the biggest Manchester United FC
Manchester United's Player of the Month Luke Shaw says Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's manner with the players has helped his recent form in two key ways.
Shaw has enjoyed a fine season, winning United's Player of the Month award three times, and has been a key part of Solskjaer's side that has been rejuvenated since the Christmas period.
But Shaw insists he has not changed any particular aspect of his game to hold down his place, but instead credits the manager with improving the atmosphere in squad.
Shaw says that has brought an improvement to his own game, as he has been given confidence to play and been allowed to enjoy his football under the new regime.
He said: “It’s hard to try and pinpoint anything that I’ve changed, I haven’t changed anything massively. I think it’s more down to confidence and enjoying myself again, a lot of which is down to the manager and the way he is with me. Read More Barcelona handed major injury boost ahead of Manchester United fixture
“He’s helped me a lot since he’s come in and I think he’s helped a lot of other players as well.
"We’re very lucky to have this job but to do it day-in, day-out – like any job – you need to enjoy it. The more you enjoy it, the more you get out of it.
"Real positive things are happening and that’s showing on the pitch but also off the pitch. This place is a much better environment.
"There are lots of positives but I just need to keep going, keep focused and keep enjoying football." Read More

thread.title: Barcelona Diperingatkan untuk Tak Remehkan Man United
thread.title_full: Barcelona Diperingatkan untuk Tak Remehkan Man United

posts.title: Barcelona Diperingatkan untuk Tak Remehkan Man United
posts.text:
Barcelona Diperingatkan untuk Tak Remehkan Man United Hendry Kurniawan, Jurnalis · Kamis 04 April 2019 22:21 WIB 0 Komentar
MANCHESTER – Manchester United bakal menjamu Barcelona tengah pekan depan dalam laga leg pertama perempatfinal Liga Champions 2018-2019. Jelang pertandingan tersebut, gelandang Man United, Andreas Pereira, memberi peringatan kepada kubu Barcelona untuk tidak meremehkan timnya.
Apabila menilik pada perhitungan di atas kertas, tak bisa dimungkiri kalau Barca memang lebih diunggulkan. Selain memiliki komposisi skuad yang lebih mumpuni, penampilan tim berjuluk Blaugrana tersebut juga bisa dibilang konsisten. Di sisi lain, Man United baru saja mendera kekalahan dari Wolverhampton Wanderers di ajang Liga Inggris. BERITA TERKAIT +
(Baca juga: Solskjaer Dipermanenkan Hanya untuk Senangkan Fans )
Kendati demikian, Pereira percaya kalau Setan Merah tetap memiliki peluang untuk menjungkalkan Barca, seperti yang mereka lakukan terhadap Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) di babak 16 besar. Terlebih lagi, Man United akan bertanding di Old Trafford, yang mana itu bisa menjadi faktor pembeda karena besarnya dukungan fans.
“Melawan klub-klub besar, kami memiliki kesempatan itu. Kami menunjukkan karakter kami. Kami menunjukkan semangat Man United yang asli dan saya pikir, setelah apa yang kami lakukan melawan PSG, tim lain akan lebih mempersiapkan duru, sehingga mereka akan lebih menghargai kami,” terang Pereira, menukil dari laman resmi Man United, Kamis (4/4/2019).
“Saya bisa membayangkan itu (bermain di Old Trafford) akan menjadi atmosfer yang luar biasa. Kami akan siap untuk itu. Kami punya banyak waktu untuk mempersiapkan. Para penggemar juga melakukannya, karena kami tidak memiliki pertandingan di akhir pekan, jadi saya tahu mereka akan bersemangat untuk menonton pertandingan (melawan Barca),” lanjutnya.
(fmh)

posts.author: Daniel Murphy
posts.title: Manchester United's Eric Bailly a 'shock summer transfer target for Real Madrid'
posts.text:
Daniel Murphy 22:00, 4 APR 2019 Sport Eric Bailly of Manchester United (Image: Chloe Knott - Danehouse/Getty Images) Manchester United centre-back Eric Bailly has emerged as a surprising transfer target for Real Madrid, according to reports.
The Sun reports that Bailly is a 'shock summer transfer target' for the La Liga juggernauts as manager Zinedine Zidane is a 'huge fan' of the defender after his previous spell in Spain.
The Ivorian spent three years in Spain first as a youth-teamer at Espanyol before establishing himself at Villarreal, where he made 47 appearances in an 18-month spell, before making his £34m move to United.
Now it's reported that Bailly is 'ready to move on after being plagued by injuries and falling down the pecking order' and The Sun claim that Madrid will be his escape route in a £35m transfer.
It's also reported that Los Blancos were trying to sign Bailly when he initially moved to Old Trafford and now 'bosses at the Bernabeu have him on a list of first-tier options.'
Read More Manchester United 'identify £128 million target to partner Paul Pogba' The report claims that Bailly has grown frustrated at United with rumours of new manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer wanting to add to his defence in the summer and no talks of an extension to the 24-year-old's current deal.
The rumours further fuel speculation that United are set to move for Madrid centre-back Raphael Varane in the summer.
United have long been linked with the Frenchman and it was reported this week that he is considering quiting the Spanish capital in favour of a move to the Premier League, even though his contract runs until 2022.
The Sun speculate that United could offer a 'player-plus-cash' deal to try and sign the World Cup winning defender.
Read More Manchester United targeting three signings in transfer window but there could be more Meanwhile, United are hoping to sell Alexis Sanchez for £50m this summer, according to reports.
The Sun claim that Solskjaer 'does not see the under-performing forward as part of his plans.'
It's reported that United will try and find a buyer at around £50m and will 'then negotiate a pay-off with Sanchez to offset his wages and make sure the deal goes through.'
The Chilean is contracted at Old Trafford until 2022.
Read More Manchester United transfer news LIVE Eric Bailly 'emerges as shock Real Madrid target' plus Varane and Sancho latest

thread.title: PSG plot revenge on Man Utd for Champions League KO by offering De Gea £400k-a-week

posts.author: Dave Fraser
posts.title: PSG plot revenge on Man Utd for Champions League KO by offering De Gea £400k-a-week
posts.text:
David De Goer PSG plot revenge on Man Utd for Champions League KO by offering De Gea £400k-a-week
The Spanish No1 is holding firm with his sky-high wages demands after being locked in an 18-month contract stand-off By Dave Fraser 4th April 2019, 4:05 pm Updated: 4th April 2019, 4:05 pm PARIS SAINT-GERMAIN are plotting their revenge on Manchester United for knocking them out of the Champions League by offering David De Gea £400k-a-week to quit.
The Spanish No1, 28, is holding firm with his sky-high wages demands after being locked in an 18-month contract stand-off with Old Trafford chiefs. Reuters 1 PSG are willing to offer De Gea £400,000-a-week to join them this summer
Now both PSG and Real Madrid are hoping to take advantage of the situation with a mega-money move.
De Gea has rejected a number of offers in recent months, with United reported to have offered £300,000 and £350,000-a-week deals.
But the Spaniard is determined to double his money and rake in £400,000 per week in a bid to close the gap to top earners such as Alexis Sanchez - currently raking in £505,000-a-week.
Now, PSG are set to swoop and pay De Gea what he believes he is worth. PSG vs MADRID
De Gea is out of contract at United next summer - and Old Trafford bosses have claimed they would rather risk losing him on a free than sell him in the coming window.
That means the French giants may play the long game, lure the ex-Atletico Madrid star next summer without paying a penny in transfer fees.
The only issue for PSG is that despite playing hardball on an improved contract, De Gea does appear to want to stay in Manchester.
Meanwhile, Real Madrid have contacted De Gea over a summer transfer - with Thibaut Courtois set to axed by the Spanish giants. MORE MAN UTD STORIES

Josh Challies Trainee Sports Wire Writer 21:00, 4 APR 2019 Sport Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Liverpool legend John Aldridge believes Jurgen Klopp is copying an aspect of Sir Alex Ferguson’s great Manchester United sides.
The Reds are currently locked in a fierce battle with Manchester City as they seek to end a 29-year wait for a league title, with Klopp’s side currently trailing by a single point heading into the final six games of the weekend.
Liverpool are showing no signs of slipping though, winning four consecutive matches across all competitions to keep the pressure on Pep Guardiola’s side.
Should Klopp end the long wait for Premier League glory at Anfield, he will establish himself as a club icon and Aldridge has spotted one way that the former Borussia Dortmund boss is showing comparisons to Ferguson .

And one key aspect of their success has crept into the current Liverpool side,” he wrote in a column for the Irish Independent.
“You could see opponents visibly cracking when United pushed for late winners in what became known as ‘Fergie Time’, and that quality is now in evidence as Liverpool aim to end their long wait for a Premier League title.”
Liverpool’s latest win over Tottenham Hotspur came in dramatic fashion as an own goal from Toby Alderweireld in added time secured all three points for the Reds.
Prior to that, the Reds scored a penalty in the last ten minutes of their win over Fulham and found the back of the net in added time against Burnley, quelling any fears of a late fightback from the Clarets.

thread.title: Premier League : les montants XXL des commissions d'agents dévoilés
thread.title_full: Premier League : les montants XXL des commissions d'agents dévoilés

posts.author: Matthieu Margueritte
posts.title: Premier League : les montants XXL des commissions d'agents dévoilés
posts.text:
Accueil > Premier League > Transferts > Premier League : les montants XXL des commissions d’agents dévoilés Premier League : les montants XXL des commissions d’agents dévoilés Publié le : Matthieu Margueritte Suivre @MattMargueritte Réputée pour être très dépensière lors des marchés des transferts, la Premier League paie en conséquence de gros montants aux agents. Mais face à ces sommes XXL, les instances du football anglais entend réagir. Liverpool rémunère très bien les agents des Reds ©Maxppp
Pour beaucoup de joueurs et d’agents, un transfert en Premier League est synonyme de gloire, au vu du prestige de la ligue anglaise où règnent plusieurs écuries de renom. Mais signer en Angleterre est également une très bonne affaire financière, même en ralliant des équipes moins cotées. Bien aidés par des droits TV domestiques vendus à hauteur de 5 milliards d’euros (sans compter les revenus pour la diffusion à l’international), les clubs de Sa Majesté ne lésinent pas lorsqu’il faut sortir le chéquier. De quoi faire le bonheur des joueurs, à qui de très gros salaires sont versés, mais aussi à leurs agents. D’ailleurs les médias anglais viennent de publier le montant total dépensé par l’ensemble des 20 formations du championnat en termes de commissions d’agents pour l’exercice 2018/2019.
Pas moins de 305,1 M€ sont ainsi allés sur les comptes en banque des représentants. Sans surprise, quatre des six premiers du classement actuel de Premier League trustent le haut du tableau. Liverpool explose d’ailleurs tous les records avec pas moins de 51,27 M€ versés aux agents ! Vingt millions d’euros plus bas, on retrouve Chelsea (31,43 M€). Les deux Manchester (28,24 M€ pour City, 24,3 M€ pour United) viennent ensuite. À noter toutefois que des équipes telles qu’Everton (19,116 M€), West Ham (14,414 M€) et Leicester (12,720 M€) ont été plus rémunératrices pour les conseillers qu’Arsenal (11,181 M€) ou Tottenham (11,141 M€). Les Spurs ont d’ailleurs été le club le moins apprécié des agents lors du dernier mercato estival puisqu’ils n’ont recruté personne. Les joueurs bientôt obligés de payer les commissions d’agents ?
Face à ces montants exorbitants, les dirigeants anglais ne vont pas rester les bras croisés et comptent bien réagir pour changer la donne selon le Telegraph . Ces derniers doivent se réunir prochainement et plusieurs mesures devraient être décidées alors que les répercussions de l’inflation des droits TV de la Premier League promet d’enflammer les prix. Ainsi, la volonté serait de plafonner les commissions d’agents, et ce, selon divers critères. À savoir qu’un travail lié à un transfert ne serait pas payé comme une simple renégociation de contrat par exemple. Mais ce n’est pas tout.
Avec l’aide de la FIFA, la Premier League et la FA (la fédération anglaise) travaillent sur un projet qui impacterait directement les joueurs. En cas de transfert, la commission de l’agent pourrait ainsi être payée par le joueur, et non par le club acheteur ( on souvient du pactole qu’avait payé MU à Mino Raiola lors du transfert de Paul Pogba ). De plus, les instances visent l’interdiction de la double commission (quand un représentant est payé par le club vendeur et celui qui achète). Enfin un retour du diplôme d’agent certifié est également à l’étude, dans le but de diminuer les nuées d’intermédiaires pillant graviter autour d’un seul transfert. Les agents sont prévenus !
Tableau des commissions d’agents versées par les clubs de Premier League :
Liverpool : 43, 795 M£ (51,27 M€) Chelsea : 26, 850 M£ (31,43 M€) Manchester City : 24, 122 M£ (28,24 M€) Manchester United : 20, 759 M£ (24,3 M€) Everton : 19, 116 M£ (22,38 M€) West Ham : 14, 414 M£ (16,88 M€) Leicester : 12, 720 M£ (14,89 M€) Arsenal : 11, 181 M£ (13, 08 M€) Tottenham : 11, 141 M£ (13,04 M€) Watford : 10, 894 M£ (12,75 M€) Bournemouth : 10, 295 M£ (12, 05 M€) Newcastle : 8, 868 M£ (10,38 M€) Fulham : 8, 234 M£ (9,64 M€) Crystal Palace : 6, 976 M£ (8,16 M€) Brighton : 6, 859 M£ (8, 02 M€) Wolverhampton : 6, 479 M£ (7,59 M€) Southampton : 6, 151 M£ (7,202 M€) Huddersfield : 5, 023 M£ (5,88 M€) Burnley : 3, 975 M£ (4,65 M€) Cardiff : 2,802 M£ (3,28 M€)

thread.title: Our homegrown hitmen can make history

posts.title: Our homegrown hitmen can make history
posts.text: How United's homegrown hitmen can make history by Share With email Copy Copy Link Marcus Rashford, Paul Pogba, Jesse Lingard, Andreas Pereira... the list of homegrown hitmen who've scored for Manchester United grew this week, when Scott McTominay bagged his first goal for the club on Tuesday. With Academy products leading the charge in the Premier League goals chart this season, we’ve embarked on a statistical study into the goalscoring menace of our in-house produce and, naturally, we're proud of the numbers involved... 29 GOALS BY GRADUATES That's how many of our 61 goals were bagged by former Academy players this season. Among the other remarkable statistics to date is that at least one graduate scored in Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's first nine Premier League matches as boss, and there have only been three fixtures from his 15 (Liverpool, Crystal Palace, Arsenal) that haven’t featured in-house scorers. Here’s how they’ve fared so far: Paul Pogba = 11 goals #MUtrivia says United have scored 61 Premier League goals so far this season, and 27 of those were netted by players who graduated from the Academy. 44 PER CENT OF OUR GOALS The 2018/19 Premier League campaign so far has comfortably housed United’s highest ever ratio for homegrown goals. Of the 61, the 27 scored by Pogba, Rashford, Lingard, Andreas and McTominay comprises just over 44 per cent of the Reds’ total; the second highest was just over 41 per cent in 1995/96, the campaign most famous for the collective arrival of the Class of ’92 in senior football. Take a look at the top percentages from our Premier League history: 1: 2018/19: 27 of 61 = 44.26% 2: 1995/96: 30 of 73 = 41.10% 3: 1997/98: 29 of 73 = 39.73% 4: 2002/03: 29 of 74 = 39.19% 5: 1992/93: 24 of 67 = 35.82% #MUtrivia says The 27 goals scored by Academy graduates this season equates to 44 per cent of the total so far. Our club record for a full campaign currently stands at 41 per cent in 1995/96. OUR TOP-SCORING GRADUATES Two current first-team players are in the all-time mix of Premier League scorers, and both men could rise up the rankings before the end of this season. Ryan Giggs = 109

thread.title: Under-23s excited to play at Old Trafford
thread.title_full: Under-23s excited to play at Old Trafford

posts.title: Under-23s excited to play at Old Trafford
posts.text:
— Manchester United (@ManUtd) April 4, 2019
Others such as Mason Greenwood, Largie Ramazani, Ethan Laird and Brandon Williams could get a taste of the Theatre of Dreams.
However, more experienced members of the squad, like full-back Lee O'Connor, will be able to pass on words of advice to ease any nerves in the dressing room. Lee O'Connor working indoors at the Aon Training Complex.
“Any time you get to play at Old Trafford, it's just an amazing experience,” said O'Connor. “It's my fourth or fifth time now and every time you get to play there, it's a real honour.
”It's definitely quite a young 23s team so I think it will be the first time for a couple of them. It should be a good experience for them.
“When you walk out at the start for the warm-up, you're used to seeing out here [at the Aon Training Complex] or Leigh Sports Village but looked up and see a 75,000-seater stadium. So it is a bit different but, as soon as the whistle blows and the game starts, it's just a normal game.
”My advice would be just to block it out and play your normal game. It's definitely very exciting for everybody. “ George Tanner did the Old Trafford stadium tour when he was younger.
George Tanner admits he cannot wait for the game to come because he was such a big United supporter growing up nearby.
“It makes it extra special,” he admitted. “Obviously, as a United fan, it was my dream to play in that stadium really.
”I've been there quite a lot and did the stadium tour a few times when I was younger. I went to the Museum and saw all the trophies. It was great. I came on as a substitute there earlier in the season and played there in the FA Youth Cup once so I've played at Old Trafford a couple of times. “ Nishan Burkart will be hoping to feature against West Brom's Under-23s.
Nishan Burkart is another youngster keen to get another crack of appearing at the ground as he looks to bank more valuable experience.
“It's always good to get the feeling of what it is like to play there, at such a brilliant stadium,” added the Swiss forward. “Obviously, it's a great pitch but so big so a lot of work will be going on out there! There might just be a few nerves, that is always a factor, but it's good to get learning about how to play in such big stadiums.
”Having a lot of fans is good to cheer us on and it might also be a disadvantage for our opponents. “
There is free entry for all supporters to Old Trafford on Friday as the Under-23s face West Brom (19:00 BST kick-off). posts.title: Las 9 caras nuevas que quiere Solskjaer en el Manchester United
posts.text:
0.Las 9 caras nuevas que quiere Solskjaer en el Manchester United Actualizado a 04-04-2019 16:46
El Manchester United tiene en mente hacer una profunda renovación de la plantilla de la próxima temporada y estos son los nombres que más suenan para llegar al conjunto de Old Trafford. 1/9 1.Kalidou Koulibaly (Nápoles)
El central senegalés es un viejo objetivo del Manchester United y sería una pieza clave para solucionar los problemas defensivos de los ‘diablos rojos’ en el eje de la zaga. 2/9 2.Raphael Varane (Real Madrid)
El central francés del Real Madrid está dispuesto a cambiar a de aires y el Manchester United lo acogería con los brazos abiertos. 3/9 3.Aaron Wan-Bissaka (Crystal Palace)
El joven lateral inglés está siendo una de las revelaciones de la Premier League y el club de Old Trafford es uno de sus más firmes pretendientes. 4/9 4.Declan Rice (West Ham)
El mediocentro del West Ham también está siendo una de las revelaciones en Inglaterra y su fichaje sería una buena incorporación ante la posible marcha de futbolistas en la medular de los ‘diablos rojos’. 5/9 5.Saúl Ñíguez (Atlético Madrid)
El centrocampista español lleva años en la agenda del Manchester United, aunque no será nada fácil sacarlo del Atlético de Madrid. 6/9 6.Bruno Fernandes (Sporting CP)
El mediapunta portugués está en busca de un reto deportivo más ambicioso y el Manchester United lleva tiempo siguiéndole la pista. 7/9 7.Joao Félix (Benfica)
Es una de las perlas del fútbol mundial y el Manchester United tiene decidido apostar por su fichaje, tal y como ocurrió con Cristiano Ronaldo en su día. 8/9 8.Jadon Sancho (Borussia Dortmund)
El joven extremo está brillando en la Bundesliga y desde los ‘diablos rojos’ están valorando muy seriamente la posibilidad de repatriar al inglés para reforzar su delantera. 9/9 9.Callum Hudson-Odoi (Chelsea)
Otro de los jóvenes talentos ingleses que están haciéndose un hueco en el panorama futbolístico. El extremo no parece por la labor de renovar por el Chelsea y termina contrato en 2020, por lo que su salida este verano parece factible. 10/9
